understanding.p: A topic set is a collection of related topics that follow the same schema and multiple topic sets can use the same schema. A topic set appears in the HTML output as a folder in the table of contents or a chapter in a print document. Individual topics in the topic set folder are presented in alphabetical order.
A document must have at least one topic set. Typically, a topic set belongs to a document set.

planning-question.planning-question-title: Do I neeed to create a new topic set?

planning-question-body.p: You could have a single topic set that contains all the topics; however, you typically want to group topics and present the topic set groups in a specific order in the table of contents. You may also want topics to follow different schemas.

how-to-answer-body.p: If you want to do any of the following, you need a new topic set:

li.p: Create a new document—every document needs at least one topic set
Introduce a new schema—the topics in a topic set follow a single schema
Group new or existing topics under a different folder or chapter in the TOC—there is one folder for each topic set in the table of contents
Change the order of topic sets in the TOC—the order of the folders in the table of contents is based on the topic-set-order element in the configuration file

doing.p: To add a topic set to the build, perform the following steps:

li.p: Create a topic set configuration file
Add a new /spfe/doc-set/topic-sets/topic-set to the SPFE configuration file

doing.p: In the topic set configuration file, include the following elements:

li.p: spfe: The root element that specifies the schema of the configuration file. SPFE provides the spfe-config schema, or you can define your own. Each build configuration file in the document must follow the same schema.
Define a unique TOPIC_SET_ID and a topic-set-id element, for example: <define name="TOPIC_SET_ID" value="spfe-development-tasks"/> <topic-set-id>${TOPIC_SET_ID}</topic-set-id>
/spfe/topic-set-type: It determines where your topic set appears in the table of contents and it must match one of the entries in the topic-set-type-order element in the SPFE configuration file
/spfe/sources: The list of directories that contain the contents of the topics
/spfe/build: The parameters that specify where to store files generated during the build
/spfe/deployment: The path to the output folder
/spfe/scripts: the list of scripts to process the topic set; if you use an existing schema, you can reuse the existing scripts

doing.p: If you want content at the top level folder, you need an index topic.
Key elements: /spfe/topic-set-id, string - name that appears in the TOC default-topic-scope, default-subject-affinity-scope
When you build your documents, if your topic set appears in the table of contents in the order you specified by using the topic-set-type, you have successfully added your topic set.
